The Accidental release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Soda Lake 2 (SL2) Geothermal Power Facility

The SL2 Geothermal Power Facility is located at 5500 Soda Lake Way, Fallon, Nevada in the county of Churchill. The facility is committed to be a responsible member of the nearby communities. Site policy dictates that the SL2 Facility continuously identify methods to identify and reduce the risk to the community and environment through implementation of inherently safe technologies and procedures. This commitment to safe and environmentally sound operations is documented in policy and safety procedures at the facility which are available to all employees who are trained to these policies and safety procedures. In the event of a fire the Fallon Fire Department will immediately be notified of the fire and for response.



Description of the Soda Lake 2 Unit Geothermal Facility and the Regulated Substance Used.



The facility uses heat from geothermal brine at approximately 327 degrees Fahrenheit to heat, through a non-contact heat exchange process, up to three pentane processes that convert the geothermal heat to electric power for sale to the local utility (NV Energy). The pentane used in the closed loop (recirculated/recycled) power generation process is the only regulated substance at the site. The facility can have on site up to 31,000 gallons of pentane being used in the processes or being stored at any given time. No more than one truck of approximately 4,200 gallons of makeup pentane is required per year. When pentane is delivered to the site it is off loaded at a designated pentane storage area and under qualified and approved safe operating procedures.



The three identical power generation processes, Organic Energy Convertors (OEC), each consists of two levels of power extraction, Level 1 (L1) and Level 2 (L2). The Pentane in each of these levels are completely isolated from one another and each circulate in a closed loop. The turbine in eac

h of these loops is directly coupled to a common generator. Each level has similar components with the exception that that OEC-4 has a recuperator. For each cycle, the power extraction starts in heat exchangers (preheaters and vaporizers) which absorb heat from the geothermal brine in order to boil and convert the pentane into its vapor phase. The vaporized pentane is then directed to turbines specially designed to convert thermal energy in the pentane to rotational mechanical energy. The turbines which are directly coupled to the same generator, in turn, rotate the generator leading to the generation of electrical power.  Pentane from the turbine is directed to air-cooled condensers with exception of OEC-4 which has the pentane go to the recuperator prior to the air-cooled condenser. The condensers then complete the condensing of pentane back to its liquid phase. From the condensers pentane falls to the suction of the feed pumps which pressurize the pentane and directs the pentane to the preheaters on all units and levels except OEC-4 which goes to the recuperator prior to the preheaters. This recuperator is to absorb heat from the pentane moving from the turbine outlet to the condensers and to the preheater in the cycle. 



The Worst-Case Release Scenario and the Alternative Release Scenario.



The Worst-Case Release Scenario evaluated was that of a ruptured pentane tank leading to a BLEVE condition using 46,000 pounds of pentane. The maximum distance to an over pressure of 1 psi is 0.3 miles (0.6 kilometers). The EPA's RMP Off site Consequence Analysis Guidelines for Worst-Case Scenario were calculated using RMP*Comp. Although there are numerous installed control measures that, in an actual event, would mitigate the release, no credit for mitigation measures was considered for this scenario.

 The Alternate Case Release Scenario evaluated based on a feed pump seal failure. This leading to a leak lasting 10 minutes and a vapor cloud fire starting immediately aft

er leak initiation.  Using RMP*Comp to perform the calculations it is estimated that the initial  pentane flow rate will be 1,201 pounds per minute leading to a 1 psi overpressure endpoint at 0.1 miles from the fire.



Accidental Release Prevention Program



The accidental release program developed for the Soda Lake Geothermal Facility is a formal program implemented to satisfy the requirements of the State of Nevada's Chemical Accident Prevention Program (CAPP), the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) and the United States Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) Risk Management Program (RMP) requirements. Additionally, it is the belief of Soda Lake Geothermal management that this management program also lead to a more efficient and profitable operation.



The Process Safety Management program consists of thirteen program "elements" which comprise:

    PSM Program Management and Document Control

    Facility and Substance Information and Safety Information (PSI)

    Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

    Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs)

    Training Programs

    Mechanical Integrity

    Management of Change (MOC) Program

    Pre-Start Up Safety Review (PSSR)

    Verification of Compliance Audit

    Incident Investigation

    Employee Participation

    Contractor Safety Program

    Emergency Action Plan



The Plant Manager is responsible for ensuring the implementation and management of the PSM program, however, all employees and contractors before doing any work on site are required to know and understand specified elements of the PSM program before undertaking any work on site. All responsibilities and requirements are specified in the PSM program.



A brief description of each element follows.



PSM Program Management and Document Control 



It is important that the Soda Lake 2 Geothermal Power Plant continues to review and amend, in a consistent manner, relevant procedures and other supporting documents. This is to ensure proced

ures are working properly and have been, and are being, developed pursuant to regulatory requirements. Also, of importance are the ready identification, accessibility and appropriate archival management of such documentation. Evidence of compliance in this regard is a requirement of external authorities such as: 

It is also important that policies, procedures, process safety information and key materials are document controlled such that the relevant revision is readily identifiable by readers and users, as applicable at any specific time, especially for auditing and historical purposes.

The Plant Manager is responsible for an ongoing review all process safety information and procedures to make certain they are regularly updated in line with changing legislative and other requirements. All superseded process safety information and procedures are to be destroyed

An appropriate review process, incorporating employee consultation, is in place per the Employee Participation Program.



This policy applies to the following Soda Lake Geothermal Power Plant documentation:

 

    Standard Safety Procedures (SSP's)

    Standard Operating Procedures (SOP's)

    Process Safety Information (PSI)



Facility and Substance Information and Safety Information (PSI)



The Soda Lake 2 Process Safety Information Management is addressed in SSP-1 Program Management and Document Control and will be in accordance with the requirements of the following: 

All Process Safety Information and Documentation will be maintained in the SSP-3 folder on Box.com.

No further mention in the procedure will be provided as SSP-1 will be the procedure used to maintain and manage this information.



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)



To establish a procedure for conducting a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for the Soda Lake 2 Geothermal Power Plant.  This procedure is required for compliance with OSHA Process Safety Management (OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119(e)).

The purpose of the PHA is to:

    Define possible hazards

associated with the facilities process that includes -pentane. 

    Identification of any previous incidents, which had a likely potential for catastrophic consequences.

    Evaluate engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards.

    Determine the consequences of failures associated with engineering and administrative controls.

    Perform facility inspection and HAZOP study to determine the safety and health of employees.

    Establish a method of addressing team's findings and recommendations; assure the recommendations are resolved in a timely manner; document what actions are taken and a written schedule of when the actions are to be completed.

The PHA will be updated and revalidated every five years to ensure the study is consistent with the processes.



Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs)



The Soda Lake 2 Facility's Standard Operating Procedure Management is addressed in SSP-1 Program Management and Document Control and will be in accordance with the requirements of the following:  

    All up to date Standard Operating Procedures maintained in the SSP-4 folder on Box.com.

    No further mention in the procedure will be provided as SSP-1 will be the procedure used to maintain and manage this information.



Training Programs



This procedure outlines the training process for all Soda Lake 2's Geothermal personnel. It outlines the use of the different tools that the trainee should use and how the training process is to be controlled by plant management. This procedure is to be managed in accordance with Program Management Plan and Document Control procedure.



All personnel are required to be familiar with The Soda Lake Geothermal Power Plant training program up to their required qualification level.

 

Employees shall be responsible for the progress of their training.



The Plant Manager is ultimately responsible for the management of the Training Program. The Plant Manager will appoint a responsible, qualified Plant Operator ("Trainer") to foll

ow up on the training process of each trainee and make sure that all the knowledge & tools are available for the trainee. The Plant Manager is also responsible to:



    Provide a safety indoctrination to each new employee as soon as possible after their hire.

    Provide a safety briefing of the precautions to be taken while training in the plant.

    Make sure that all training documents are in place.

    Ensure instructional materials, methods used for comprehension and methods used to document successful 

          training are developed, reviewed and approved in accordance with the Program Management Plan and Document 

          Control procedure.

    Make sure that the trainer has all the tools required to provide the professional guidance for the trainee.

    Ensure that the trainee and trainer understand the process and their responsibilities.

    Outline a schedule for completion of the training (set measurable goals). And follow up on this schedule.

The Trainers responsibilities are: 

    Provide direction, technical help and answer questions about plant operations/ equipment/ procedural matters

    Direct the trainee to focus on the fundamentals. 

    Help the trainee with plant orientation & provide the guidance for the "walk through" tasks. 

    Make sure the trainee has all the literature/ technical documents.

    Follow up on the progress of the trainee using the qualification checklist.

    Supervise the completion of the qualification written tasks (drawings and lists) and submit the written 

          documents to the Plant Manager.

       Supervise the completion of the qualification practical tasks (maintenance and logs) and review with the 

       trainee.

      Report to the Plant Manager of the qualification card completion and trainee's readiness to take the written 

        test.

      It is the trainer's responsibility to accompany the trainee in all learning tasks that are held outside/ in 

          the control center.

The Trainee will utilize but is no

t limited to the following documents:

    Qualification program 

    P&IDs, Electrical drawings & PFDs

    Vendor Manuals

    O & M Manuals

    Standard Operating Procedures (SOP's)

    Process and Control Narrative

    Safety Data Sheets (SDS's)

    Standard Safety Procedures (SSP's)

    Plant Safety System Description

    Management of Change (MOC) Program



Mechanical Integrity Program



  Is used to assure the continued integrity of process equipment and that all process equipment is designed, 

     constructed, installed, and maintained to minimize the risk of process releases.

  Identify and categorize all process equipment and instrumentation.

  Development of written maintenance procedures and a quality assurance program.  

  Training for process maintenance activities, inspection and testing, and correction of deficiencies in equipment 

     that is outside acceptable limits as defined by the process safety information. 

  This procedure is to be managed in accordance with SSP-1 - Program Management Plan and Document Control.



Management of Change (MOC) Program



The intent of this procedure is to require management of all modifications to equipment, structures, buildings, procedures, raw materials and processing conditions other than replacement in kind by identifying and reviewing them prior to implementation of the change. Minimum requirements for management of change include: establishing written procedures to manage change; addressing the technical basis, impact on safety and health, modification to operating procedures, necessary time period, and authorizations required; informing and training employees and contractors affected; and updating process safety information and operating procedures or practices.



  The following is a list of examples but is not limited to where an MOC procedure is necessary:

    New projects that involve tie-ins, equipment additions or modifications, increase throughput or the use of a 

      different raw material or additives.

Significant changes in operating conditions, including pressures, temperatures, flow rates or process conditions 

      outside the established ranges set for the process and mechanical design.

   Changes in alarms, instrumentation and control schemes.

   Changes to the process equipment that cause changes in the facilities pressure relief requirements.

   Bypass around equipment normally in service or running without equipment normally in service.

   Changes in operating procedures, including procedures for start-up, normal shutdown and emergency shutdown.

   Temporary connections, utilities, electrical, process, temporary repairs, pipe clamps. Etc.

   Replacement of components that are not in kind including gaskets, valves, bolts, etc. A MOC is not required for 

      components which satisfy the in use/approved design specifications.

   Replacement of equipment with equipment of different design specifications, a change of manufacturer does not 

      require an MOC if the specifications for the new equipment are the same as the one removed.

  This procedure shall be maintained to ensure it satisfies OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard 29 CFR, 

      Part 1910; and EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) Standard 40 CFR, Part 68 confirmations that:

  The technical basis for change is appropriate.

  Industrial safety, health and environmental impacts of a change are understood.

  Procedures are modified as appropriate for change.

  Training is held as appropriate for change.

  Preventive Maintenance/Mechanical Integrity program is modified as appropriate for change.

  Determination of PSSR requirements as appropriate for change.

  Determination of the time necessary to make the proposed change.

  Permissible time period is established for temporary changes.

  Appropriate personnel authorize a change.

  The Process Safety Information (PSI) is updated as appropriate for change.

  Management of Change (MOC) procedures ensure proper pr

ocess changes are evaluated for safety and health 

      consequences and approved before being implemented.



MOC procedures ensure that employees involved in operating a process, and maintenance and contract employees whose job tasks will be affected are informed of, and trained in, all elements of the PSM program and all CAPP elements.



MOC will verify each process change will be audited to ensure the change has been properly reviewed and implemented as proposed, that proper documentation has been made to drawings, diagrams, operating procedures, and standard safety procedures and that subsequent operations, after the change has been implemented, have not indicated the existence of unrecognized hazards.



The Plant Manager has the primary responsibility for ensuring all affected departments and employees (including contractors) have been informed about any process change prior to it being implemented.



In order to maintain the continuity of a chemical process and allow for those instances where periodic "fine-tune" adjustments are required, an operator must have the flexibility to be able to make necessary process changes to process operating conditions. These process changes are allowable without the need of MOC forms if they are within the range of safe operating limits specified in the Operating Procedure.



In order to maintain the integrity of an operating process and allow for those instances where "Emergency actions" are required, an operator must have the flexibility to take immediate actions to make necessary process changes to process operating conditions. These Emergency process changes are reserved for those situations that are legitimately urgent and require some type of immediate action to stabilize and bring a potentially catastrophic situation under control. These actions will be allowable without the need of MOC forms if they are within the range of safe operating limits specified in the Emergency Operating Procedure.

MOC ensures that Pr

ocess Safety Information (PSI) and Operating, Maintenance, and Emergency Procedures are updated as appropriate.

  The MOC program applies to all PSM covered processes within the plant and Administrative Reviews.

  The MOC program applies to changes in the following:

    Process Chemicals

    Process Technology

    Process Equipment including structural components

    Process Controls and Parameters

    Policies and Procedures

    Administration, Organization, and Staffing



Pre-Start Up Safety Review (PSSR)



The Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) Program was developed to ensure completeness, operability and safety of all new or modified equipment, systems and subsystems; to assure that appropriate safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place; and to verify that a process hazard analysis has been performed.



The PSSR includes the use of construction walk down checklists for mechanical, electrical and control systems, construction document audits, the verification of procedure development, performance of a PHA and MOC, verification of safety, operation and maintenance training and the documentation and correction of deficiencies and the confirmation of completion.



Verification of Compliance Audit



Ensure the SL2 Geothermal Plant certifies, at least once every three (3) years, that an evaluation has been performed of whether adequate procedures and practices have been developed, implemented, and are being followed as required by the OSHA Standards for General Industry Process Safety Management (PSM) and the Environmental Protection Agency Risk Management Plan (RMP).

   Verify the compliance audit is conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process. 

   Make certain the facility develops a report of the audit findings. 

   The facility shall then promptly determine and document an appropriate response to each of the findings of the 

      compliance audit and document that deficiencies have been corrected. 

   To

confirm the facility shall retain the two (2) most recent compliance audit reports. 

   To ensure that the Plant Manager properly maintains, develops and implements the Compliance Audits.

It is the responsibility of the Plant Manager to ensure the Compliance Audit element is maintained and updated as necessary to reflect procedures at the Facility. As such, the Plant Manager will ensure that only the most up-to-date version of this document is available.



Incident Investigation



Incident investigation is the process of identifying causes of incidents and implementing steps to prevent similar events from occurring. The intent of an incident investigation is for employers/employees to learn from past experiences and thus avoid repeating past mistakes. 

This procedure is designed to meet the strict criteria of OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM), and EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP).



The Incident Investigation process should be applied to all Accidents, Incidents, Incidents that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release, and Near Misses that occur. OSHA and NAC definitions of these conditions are as follows:



?Incident: An unplanned, undesired event that adversely affects completion of a task.

?Catastrophic Release: An uncontrolled emission, fire or explosion involving one or more highly hazardous substances 

   or explosives that presents imminent and substantial endangerment to the health of the employees, the public 

   health or the environment.  The term includes events that occur within a building or other structure that 

   contains the substance or explosive.

?Accident: An undesired event that results in personal injury or property damage.

?Near Miss: An incident where no property was damaged and no personal injury sustained, but where, given a slight 

   shift in time or position, damage and/or injury easily could have occurred. Note: a Near Miss does not 

   necessarily require a release of process fl

uids. Any incident that could have reasonably resulted in a 

   catastrophic release under different circumstances should be considered a Near Miss

Contractor Safety Program



To establish a screening process for contractors performing maintenance or repair work on covered processes that involve highly hazardous materials.

Ensure all contractors accomplish desired job tasks without compromising the health and safety of employees and contractor employees at the SL2 Geothermal Power Plant.

Ensure contractor employees are trained on performing work safely and are aware of all hazards related to the job and applicable elements of the Emergency Action Plan (SSP-13), Lockout/Tagout (SSP-15), Hot Work (SSP-16), Safe Work (SSP-17), Personal Protective Equipment (SSP-18), Hazardous Chemical Communication (SSP-19), and Working at High Elevations (SSP-20).



Emergency Action Plan



It is important that the SL2 Geothermal Power Facility develops, continues to review and amend, in a consistent manner, its Emergency Action Plan. This is to ensure the Emergency Action Plan (EAP) works properly and has been, and is being, developed pursuant to regulatory requirements. Evidence of compliance in this regard is a requirement of external authorities such as: 

Th

e Plant Manager is responsible for an ongoing review of the Emergency Action plan IAW SSP-1 Program Management and Document Control to ensure that all required elements are included, up to date, and that any changes are documented IAW SSP-7 Management of Change.

The EAP will be reviewed on an annual basis IAW SSP-1 Program Management and Document Control.  The Plant Manager will assign appropriate qualified personnel to review the EAP. Once reviews are completed, they will be given back to the Plant Manager for final review.  Upon completing the final review the Plant Manager will date and initial the index page for those procedures.

The review will ensure the procedure is accurate, working properly and pursuant to regulatory requirements.

Events that may cause a need for EAP review shall include but are not limited to MOC's that affect the employee alarm system, changes in plant management, and changes in first responders or their management, and etc. These will most likely require a revision to the EAP and all changes to the EAP shall require a MOC.  

All changes to the EAP will require a MOC and notification be sent and documented to first responders.



Five Year Accident History



There have been no accidents involving n-pentane that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or shelterings in place within the past 5 years.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



There are no current plans to improve safety, however, routine reviews and or accident investigations, should an accident occur, will strive to identify any safety improvement measures needing to be implemented. Should any improvements be identified they will be implemented as soon as possible.
